Great insights as usual, thanks Marques! I genuinely think this is all about price point and accessibility. For anyone who's done an Apple Vision Pro demo in the Apple Store, they will know how insane and potentially game changing it could be for everyone. The fact is people aren't going to drop $3500 for a supplementary (or what they see as supplementary) product. People still need their phones and their laptops/iPads, so this isn't a primary device, at least not in the current iteration, so not being able to squeeze AVP into people's tech budget cannot be underestimated as a barrier..  The high price point has also means most people haven't actually tried AVP themselves, and as someone who thought it was cool whilst watching all of the initial videos and hype, I couldn't prepare myself for just how blown away I was when I finally tried it last month for the first time, I remember thinking "I NEED to have this in my life!" So the magic of this device ONLY comes with trying it, and most people won't - again because of the price.   I don't see AR glasses in the same category, they're much more practical and allow us to do everyday tasks more efficiently and simultaneously. Whilst they do and will offer some really neat features, it's a completely different product line and it's not about immersion it's about utility and accessibility, but they definitely have wider everyday appeal. It's for this reason that I believe Apple Vision Pro will still have it's viral moment, Apple will unveil a cheaper more comfortable accessible version or Vision Pro with arguably even more functionality, it's just a matter of when not if.  It definitely feels like Apple is trying to get ahead of the curve or at least, be in the race with AR glasses. I think it's a smart decision, but I do wish they hadn't dropped development of AVP. If any company could resource multiple high-end products â€“ Apple can! But I think it's a decision resulting from the market moving at such a rapid pace, and with all of the issues with Apple Intelligence and failures of internal resources, they're being more focused and cautious with future projects, which is sensible, and whilst disappointing for AVP, I think it means we will get a REALLY good AR glass product as a result.  I'm confident Apple will return to AVP once glasses are up and walking.   In the mean time I will be getting the AVP soon and cannot wait! EDIT - I work in AV in my day job and I'm a video editor so I get that my reaction to and use case of AVP is going to be pumped up compared tp most regular tech users. For me, those little incremental upgrades have tipped the scales and I've been saving!
VR headsets and smart glasses are widely considered intrusive to both social life and privacy. They will likely remain niche products, so thereâ€™s no need for major upgrades.

Apple's team should really pivot they're usageof this device from "outside wear augmented reality", to "indoor multi-screen station". They could easelly have 3 tiers for it: Vision Pro - as is. Vision - Standard (office) edition. Battery sold seperatly. Could be plugged to a computer or to standard power outlet. Maybe ditch the front "eye" screen and/or minimize gestures capture (could be replaced by wristband, pad, keyboard, pencil, etc; depending on the intended use). All this to REDUCE PRICE! Useful to professionals who want/need multiple screens: movie editors, ilustration designers, 3d scultures, stock exchange investors, even writers using multiple sources, etc.  Lite - Home (leisure) edition. The single best/most use people praise, and get put of, it is Home Cinema. So, no frontal screen, no frontal camera, reduced or no tracking gestures. Still useful for gaming, since even non-VR titles could be played on a big screen and have head tracking. Or just have multiple screens for whatever use. ğŸ§  Summary Appleâ€™s second-generation Vision Pro headset gets a modest upgrade: the new M5 chip and a redesigned Dual Knit Band. While performance improves slightly, the core hardware remains unchangedâ€”same cameras, displays, frame, and weight. The real story? Apple seems to be quietly pivoting away from headsets toward smart glasses, acknowledging that the Vision Pro hasnâ€™t become the mainstream hit they hoped for.  ğŸ” Highlights 0:20 M5 Chip Arrives  Apple introduces the base M5 chip in Vision Pro, iPad Pro, and 14" MacBook Pro.  No M5 Pro/Max yet; high-end devices like Mac Studio still on older chips.  1:51 Hardware: Mostly the Same  Vision Pro retains same frame, sensors, displays, and battery.  No weight reduction; in fact, itâ€™s slightly heavier due to the new band.  3:09 Dual Knit Band Upgrade  Replaces the uncomfortable Solo Knit Band.  Adds tungsten counterweights and adjustable dials for better comfort.  Available separately for $99.  4:52 Performance Gains  Faster app loading, better rendering, and ~20% longer battery life.  Minor visual improvements (e.g., 120Hz refresh vs. 100Hz).  Most users wonâ€™t notice the difference.  6:36 Market Shift & Competition  Samsung launches its own XR headset (â€œProject Moohanâ€) with Android XR.  Few other companies are competing in high-end headset space.  7:44 Smart Glasses Rising  Metaâ€™s Ray-Ban smart glasses show faster innovation and broader appeal.  Lower social penalty makes them more wearable in public.  9:14 Appleâ€™s Strategic Pivot  Vision Pro mostly used for movies and gathers dust.  Apple reportedly cancels lighter â€œVision Pro Airâ€ and shifts focus to smart glasses.  Reflects broader industry trend: trimming down headsets vs. building up glasses.

It must be the design and manufacturing expense that headset makers meet head-on that prohibits excessive competition. Varjo left the prosumer market completely, focussing on industry to buy its $5k-10k product. Despite being one of the best PC headsets, we're still awaiting Valve's second headset on top of its first...from 2020. Apple has singularly been the outlier in this space, taking very little out of its profit (and any of its megatons of cash) to build and sell these units. It would seem their economics would outrun even Samsung on that playground given their cash hoard. But no, Apple is completely bypassing the headset market, and now that they have this beast out there, they're likely not going to invest much more finding a way to make it less expensive to build. Their focus will be on glasses.

The main issue with the Vision Pro is its lack of actually engaging videogames. If I could start playing some sort of COD like on a VR headset but with the added benefit of maybe playing that game in a virtual scenario which is basically real, it would be soo appealing. Like imagine fighting a war with people inside your own house. You scan that beforehand to create the map and lobby and then ask your friends to join in and you start playing in it. Not even just COD but whatever. That would be sick. Vision Pro has a HUUUUUGE potential in the videogame market and I think many gamers would be willing to spend that amount of money on it given how many people I know whose gaming setup cost way more than 3,5k to build up. Sadly though, I don't think that would happen anytime soon. And also whenever it will happen, I doubt it will be Apple the one winking their eye to gamers. It's just not in their business model. But try to think of it. Would you buy a product like that, even with a price tag of 3,5k if it could actually allow you to play games in an "AR mode"? I know I would really consider that towards the top of my wishes.

Apple Vision Pro will mostly accelerate in gaming/fitness, creative work, and media, but not much in heavy-duty use. The real breakthrough will happen when Apple moves beyond just consumer products and starts making VR/AR devices for professional, industrial, or research applications â€” like teleoperation, scientific simulations, medical training, or machine control. Thatâ€™s where it could actually take off. Right now, itâ€™s amazing tech, but itâ€™s mostly limited to casual use.

To be honest its not far fetched to replace mobiles with batteries for smart eye wear, especially for those that already use eyewear.   Theres also the possibility to mass produce smart eyewear that automatically focus (maybe even default focus to use minimal battery)as opposed to making presciption lenses. Can even adjust to your eyes enhancing your vision as required. Thats where I see a possible direction for tech in the future, enhancing human senses.

I went back to the review a last year to see what his exact words were about comfort. 1 year ago: "all of the weight up at the front against basically these two pressure points, right above your eyes and right on your cheeks.... so hard to wear this for more than about 30-45 minutes."  So he went from describing it as distributing the weight across your forehead and cheeks, to now saying it concentrates lots of weight on your nose. He never said anything in the original review about the nose being a pressure point. On top of that, he has gone from saying back then it could be worn for 30-45 minutes, to now admitting it's unbearable after 10 minutes. Fascinating how the truth comes out only after he's given an updated new model with better comfort.

The Vision Pro doesn't really need changes. It needs (a) a smaller price tag and (b) software. In the software front, Apple was unable to convince large companies to invest in it. There's still no Youtube app, and that would be trivial for a company the size of Google to build. The fact that they didn't bother is telling. Apple is now in competition with the streaming industry, and has alienated many developers. I was actually surprised that there wasn't a gold rush to make Vision Pro apps _even without the user base_. The Apple of a few years ago (say, a decade) would certainly attract enough attention. There's something really odd going on with the company itself, the Vision Pro state is just a symptom.

I have one and think itâ€™s the best piece of tech Iâ€™ve ever had. The capability of the headset itself is amazing. For me the absolute best use of the headset is one which the rest of the world isnâ€™t setup for yet and apple havenâ€™t pushed (but strangely is their biggest marketing/selling point on phones) - personal home photos and videos but in VR180 (if you donâ€™t know what that is, look it up!) I have a dual lens camera which is homemade but canon do sell one at an eyewatering price. It takes dual 180 degree 16k photos and video which you can import onto the headset and literally rewatch in insane quality on the vision pro display. Itâ€™s like youâ€™re looking through your eyes again in 3 dimensional viewing and at the correct scale (which is something you donâ€™t realise current viewing of media doesnâ€™t do, it has a huge impact in the reality of it). Itâ€™s the real deal and is unbelievable, itâ€™s truly the future and is already here but itâ€™s not accessible and not widely known about. When i show my friends the VR180 photos they all have no idea it existed and they are blown away by it. I bought the vision pro and VR180 camera upon the birth of my daughter and we can put the headset on and look at her aged 1 day old in the exact same way! It makes traditional photos seem like the stone age. The vision pro itself does take a small 3d picture but itâ€™s nothing compared to VR180.  Unfortunately as vision pro is so expensive there is a small number of people who have them. This combined with a misplaced negative opinion about what it does mainly fuelled by its price, means it has not received the investment from developers that it needs. Itâ€™s a different offering to quest 3, those who compare them like the old playstation vs xbox argument are completely missing the point. I do understand their frustration. If it was more accessible to the masses the future development of this product line would change the world like it should be. Instead, for most people itâ€™s only useful for watching films on (viewing quality on vision pro is the best youâ€™ll see) The Apple VR180 documentaries and ringside sports viewing are unreal, my grandad gets to see elephants again like heâ€™s there again in his youth when he could travel, he cried when he saw this. The few apps which did get development are amazing. Due to this slow uptake and this stagnant innovation from apple, itâ€™s clear that itâ€™s before itâ€™s time. I have no doubt this will be the future. I am sad to see that the innovation is not as fast as I want it to be and the camera market is non existent. I am so glad they made it available so I already get to make use of that future, when Iâ€™m old I will one of few people my age who can look back and relive memories of my family and my daughter growing up.

I went down the rabbit hole trying to find the right productivity headset that would allow me to untether me from the desk. Eventually I realized these immersive â€œgogglesâ€ werenâ€™t it. I ended up with XReal glasses. In reality, I need something that allows me to work inconspicuously, as if I have a big monitor; when sitting outside on a picnic table, flying, or generally trying to work away from my desk.   The downside has been that because it needs to be connected via USB, our corporate security software shuts down data when it senses the USB plugged in. The workaround requires that I plug an hdmi in to the computer, plug XReal usb into output plug of hdmi adapter,the power usb into said adapter and into the laptop with a data blocker adapter. Someone needs to make a set of glasses with the proper pixels to present the augmented reality monitor in a large size, wirelessly. Interaction with the augmented reality is a bonus. XReal is pretty close.

I have an Apple Vision Pro M2 and even though I overall don't regret purchasing it, I really just have no good reason to spend another nearly $5K on an Apple Vision Pro M5. Yes, that is what my AVPM2 cost after getting the 1TB storage, plus AppleCare, plus taxes, around $4800 as I recall. I get it that Apple never marketed the AVP as a VR device but that is where the attraction is for a lot of  people overall and it is in the VR games.  I sorta had the "Fields Of Dreams" mentality when it came to the AVPM2 meaning "if you build it, they (developers) will come".  Except the gaming developers for the most part never showed up.  Sure there are a handful of VR games like Job Simulator, Demeo, Vacation Simulator, Synth Riders, Fruit Ninja but those are mostly very old games now for any VR headset.  Honestly, as fantastic graphically, as the AVPM2 appears, is it even capable of playing the plethora of VR games that you see on the Meta Quest 3, if developers chose to port any of those games over??  Like Metro Awakening VR, Alien Rogue Incursion VR, Behemoth VR, etc.  I have never seen any evidence in the AVPM2 that it is even capable of a 1st Person Shooter game thus far.  That has always been where my disappointment has been meaning there are not a lot of actual VR games.  I always felt that if Apple had truly worked with VR developers and had launched with 20+ actual great VR games that it would have been way more successful.  As it is, we keep getting these AR games that, in my opinion, don't have long term appeal. Anyway, been supporting Apple for many decades, and keep hoping for more VR gaming support from developers. People are quick to dismiss these as useless, but one very real use case is training - in the manufacturing environment (especially aerospace) it's significantly cheaper to onboard someone by having them toss on a headset and teach them virtually. $3500 is pennies compared to the cost of getting actual components (that are constantly changing) in the hands of a new hire and taking up other resources and space, especially when you can take a ton of existing CAD to make a repeatable and adaptable environment. I don't know exactly to what extent companies are leveraging that but the little I've seen at my own company I'd bet that is their main market while also getting some sales from individuals that want to watch YouTube and scroll the socials 1/2" from their eyeballs.

Apple should rethink the design of Vision Pro. Instead of building a full computer inside the headset, they can keep only the display system, sensors, and the R1 chip for camera processing and calibration, and remove the main CPU and heavy processing hardware from the headset. The battery can be built inside the Vision Pro for convenience, and the external pack can become an optional CPU module.  Then the Vision Pro could connect through Type-C or Thunderbolt to an iPhone, iPad, or Mac, and use the processing power of that device. That way, if someone already has a powerful MacBook or iPhone, they donâ€™t need to pay again for a second CPU inside the headset. They just connect it and instantly get full performance with zero lag through Thunderbolt.  For people who want to use the Vision Pro as a standalone computer, Apple could sell the external CPU module separately, similar to the current battery pack but with actual processing hardware inside it. This would make the Vision Pro more modular, more affordable, and more flexible.

There are a few things Iâ€™d like to comment here. The first is that this product is like a laptop, the design of a laptop rarely changes. The MacBook Pro with the M5 looks the same like the MacBook Pro with the M4, correct? In an ideal world, you would take your Mac to an Apple Store and have it upgraded with the latest chip, more RAM and add more storage. In reality, they will always just launch a new product for a higher  spec. Secondly, this product is a computer. I know that special computing sounds too fancy, but it is indeed a computer with a different interface. Unlike it, the smart glasses are a wearable, just like a smart watch. Which device proves to be more useful and with a higher value, taking also into consideration the price, indeed, only time will say. I just wanted to point out these couple of things.

When AirPods were first released, many mocked them and criticized early adopters. Now, theyâ€™re a standard accessory for many. Similarly, while the Vision Pro may seem stagnant to some, critics are overlooking its groundbreaking potential as we enter a new digital era. The first iteration of any technology is always exciting but rarely widely adopted right away.   Consider the early days of mobile phones bulky and impractical or the first wired headphones. I think the glasses win here. Because: - Convenience: You can just put them on and boom, you are in. There's not much hassle to it. People with glasses are already doing the same thing everyday; take them out of the case, put them on and they go about their routine. The glasses doesn't hamper your routine. - Price: Glasses will be widely used and will have a lower price tag. - Non-full Immersion: People will appreciate if immersion is not full, at least for the average consumer. If you are working and people often need your attention then glasses do not compromise it, where as the the VR/AR headsets needs you to remove them or pause/stop whatever you are doing to give your full attention to someone.  The headsets only win in one category: Full immersion. Other than that, it not convenient, its not pocket friendly and it obstructs your senses, not to remind you, the screens are literally 2 centimeters from your eyes which causes you screen fatigue which isn't great for in the long run.  However, it's really an engineering marvel to have these products exist the way they do.

Quick thought MB:  maybe if we extrapolate Vision Pro and Meta Ray-ban Display into Apple past we can know where they are going.  So Vision Pro and Meta Quest are kinda like the Apple Lisa and the Xerox Star, maybe not in that order, but you get the drill.  A grandeur imagineering of what's coming but not really the exact vision people want.  Larry Tesler which invented the Alto, helped on the Star and took full ownership of the Lisa was more famous for the invention of copy-paste and WYSIWYG didn't quite got it even after 3 different approaches.  So this might be the case with the VR headsets, the form factor might be all wrong and the interface might be a little off.  But the Meta Ray-Ban Display might be the Apple Macintosh which was a proto laptop just with a CRT and a detachable keyboard.  Today we know those two were a mistake and that people wanted an integrated system (like the Amiga 1200) but that also included an LCD display and a trackpad, just like the First PowerBooks.  Meta's greatest achievement it's the Meta Neural Band but they need more to advance that device. Eventually they could invent the VGA of Smart Glasses, but they need to think outside of their box and stop forcing only Meta only apps there.

â€œWhatâ€™s Going on with Apple Vision Pro?â€:  Apple Vision Pro 2 (2025): The second-gen Vision Pro headset keeps the same design, displays, sensors, and core features as the original but upgrades the processor from M2 to the new M5 chip.  Whatâ€™s New: The main upgrade is a redesigned, much more comfortable dual-knit band, which distributes the weight betterâ€”but actually results in a slightly heavier device. You can also buy this new band separately for the original Vision Pro.  Performance: The M5 chip brings faster app loading, a minor increase in rendered pixels, and about 20% more battery life. But these are small improvementsâ€”most everyday users wonâ€™t notice dramatic differences.  Software: All Vision Pros now get new visionOS 26 features, including better personas, pinnable widgets, and converting photos into spatial scenes.  No Major Redesign: The core complaints from the first version (heaviness, comfort) persist except for the improved band. Cameras, displays, and general form factor are unchanged.  Market Context: Samsung has entered the market with its Android XR headset, but otherwise, few companies are releasing direct Vision Pro competitors. Meanwhile, the smart glasses category (like Meta Ray-Bans) is advancing rapidly and becoming more appealing to regular users.  Appleâ€™s Strategic Shift: Usage data shows most people use Vision Pro mainly for movies, and many units are gathering dust. Apple appears to be scaling back ambitionâ€”reportedly canceling lighter Vision Pro versions and shifting focus to smart glasses, where social acceptance and utility are higher.  Industry Trend: Tech firms are attacking â€œmixed realityâ€ from two directions: big, powerful headsets like Vision Pro (trimming them down) or smart glasses (building them up). The latter approach is gaining real-world traction.  Bottom line: The Vision Pro 2 offers modest technical improvements. The industry is watching whether XR headsets or lightweight smart glasses will win the future of â€œface computersâ€â€”for now, more people prefer smart glasses for everyday use.

I want to cook without taking my eyes off the movie, walk the dog, jog in the evening/morning twilight, ride a bike, or go shopping. I don't want a cable tugging me to my phone/battery on my belt. Give me lightweight, completely clear aviator glasses with a display and removable tinted lenses, put the battery and ALL the electronics, including the processors, in a separate unit on my neck like a Viture necklace, and let me watch movies, TV shows, and read books, comics, and manga, but for at least 10-12 hours without recharging, not just a couple of hours. I'm comfortable wearing heavy, full-size headphones around my neck; it's definitely more comfortable than having that weight on my nose or on a wire in my pants. Leave only the displays, glasses, and camera on my nose, maybe. I don't need a dumb AI assistant that understands only every third word. The camera isn't that heavy, and I can live without the hand-tracking video system; the virtual keyboard is inconvenient anyway. Gaming with glasses is also unnecessary, considering how many dongles and pairing time it requires. Leave me the wristband with a tiny domino touchpad on the pendant for navigation, if your fÃ¼hrer-Zuckerberg bought all the rights to muscle tracking. A small credit-card-sized Bluetooth keyboard is enough for me to type. Or split it into two controllers on wristbands. I HATE sluggish, slow body-tracking, ever since the XBOX 360. Give users something they'll actually use, not something that makes you look pretentious.

For anyone who wants at least as good, if not better, quality optics, FOV, etc. as the Apple Vision Pro but just want to use pure VR (not MR/AR stuff) than I highly, highly recommend checking out the Pimax Dream Air. The Pimax Dream Air comes with an updated version of the Sony Micro-OLED panels in the AVP while delivering 110 to 115-ish degrees H.FOV and around 100 degrees stereo overlap - the largest h.FOV of any OLED headset in the market and one of the largest, if not the largest, stereo overlap of any headset. For comparison, the AVP's h.FOV is only around 100 and has poor-to-average stereo/binocular overlap of around 80 degrees. Weight-wise, the Dream Air weighs under 170 g (under 0.37 lbs) compared to the Vision Pro's 650 to 800 grams (1.43 to 1.76 lbs) excluding battery. The Pimax does all that while costing only 36% to 46% of the Apple at 2000 to 2300 USD VS the AVP's 5000 to 5600 USD.

I think the main problem with the vision pro is the software ecosystem. Apple is pitching this like a wearable computer (with specs to match) but the software model is like the iPhone and iPad. The benefit of a Mac Is that you can develop software on a Mac, compile on a Mac, then run that software without needing to get app store approval, pay a cut to apple etc. This allows developers to easily play around with the hardware and make compelling software (which you need to move units). The apple vision pro is a marvelous piece of hardware with no compelling apps!   I am an aerospace engineer and if I can do parametric CAD on this thing I would pick it up in 2 seconds, but that isn't going to happen if the software distribution model is like an iPad. And if the only things you can run on this thing are glorified iPhone apps, its no wonder they are losing out to cheaper smart glasses which can also run smartphone apps. This is a PC level piece of hardware which needs PC level software support in order to succeed

What's super funny about the Vision Pro is Apple basically just stole Microsoft's idea. Microsoft tried doing this a decade before everyone else. WMR (Windows Mixed Reality) was envisioned to become what Apple Vision Pro is. They wanted to blend both virtual reality with the real world. That was their end goal. They just were too early and the tech wasn't there yet. And Microsoft being Microsoft they gave up instead of keeping at it. I had the cheaper VR headset but the higher end ones like the Samsung and eventually the HP G2 (Underrated as a VR headset as it had unmatched displayed for immersion) and then the Hololens which was the high end device Microsoft was working on which was their Vision Pro basically. Nothing changed on purpose so that companies who are developing sdks and applications for the Apple Vision Pro donâ€™t have to throw out half of their effort. Iâ€™m not choosing the Apple Vision Pro because itâ€™s best but rather because those other devices will be discontinued soon. The executives at Apple need as little reason as possible to pull the plug on this project, because it is an incredibly difficult market to find success in when you consider that in the 10 years since the first marketable MR device was released (Microsoft HoloLens 1), every single MR device released has lost the company and investors billions of dollars. Having just watched the Tested review of the M5 version of Vision Pro, it's interesting to hear the differences between folks that use the VP near daily and folks like yourself that are a lot more novelty/casual use. Neither are wrong and both make good points, but the interesting thing is there's indepth review from folks that are all in and then there's yeah, but let's look at Vision Pro vs whoever else is making something similar (note: MAN...could that Samsung look more like a knock-off in both hardware and software? Damn.) I'm nowhere near one of those Apple-can-do-no-wrong fanboys, but I'm taking the Vision Pro from the perspective that it's emerging tech and Apple hasn't abandoned it just because the numbers weren't what might have been expected. I like everything you had to say, except for 2 things: we all need to stop emphasizing the price tag. Macbooks, Mini Studio, Mac Pro...none of it is cheap, so why are we laboring over the price of the Vision Pro? Well, because it's seen as a non-essential, luxury niche item and WHOA it's SOOO EXPENSIVE! But for what the tech is, it's really not. Hell, my Powerbook 1400 was over $3k back in the late 90s. The second thing is when has Apple ever had a product that was a straight up, smash hit, clearing the shelves at introduction? Pretty much never. Apple has always wanted to be that, but the reality is that they are more of a slow burn company. Their tech is a slow tide and it eventually catches on and many others make knock offs along the way which only shows off how good the original products are. Yes, other companies are making stuff and they are making it cheaper. If those are the priorities, have at it. Everyone should buy what they want and if that's glasses instead of a headset, have at it. Who cares? I know the Vision Pro isn't for everyone, currently, but it's no Newton. It's not going away. Unless you think about now the iPhone was just the next version of the Newton and the Newton never really went away! Ha! Anyway, solid stuff and nice review, man! Thanks so much for all your work!

I have thought about these for a while. I'm still of the opinion that these devices should be an accessory, an extension of a smartphone than trying to replace it, kind of like smart watch. Those haven't really caught on because they are still just a smartphone, but we have not been able to squeeze smartphone functionalities into smart watch and that's understandable, even desirable I would argue. This suggests that the smart glass should act more like a smart display. With better wireless communication technologies like 5G or Wifi7, I feel it's reaching the point where with a bit of tricks and optimisation; we can offload much of the processing somewhere else like a phone and the smart glass can act as display, interface and data gathering point for them. Trying to do too much on those glasses would be a mistake. Even Meta's implementation feels as if it's trying to do too much on very limited real estate. Much better to leave the heavy lifting somewhere else and do the things that others suck at. If anything, the most exciting thing about Meta implementation is the wrist band thing. Make that work and interface with smart glass will be realised.

The Vision Pro is meant to be a computer that replaces the laptop for frequent travel that wants a large desk setup, or computer work in strange places and the in pipeline is to be more collaborative.   Glasses are an accessory to the smartphone, like earbuds, and watches are.

You touched on the social aspect as a reason people aren't wanting to use the vision pro, and specifically you talked about it seeming 'nerdy'. I absolutely agree with that, but I think there is a deeper issue at play.  Technology is cool and using better technology is almost always even cooler. But even as we get more advanced with all this, there's still an innate human lust for nature, friends, family - in short, real life.   When COVID restrictions were easing, people didn't stay indoors and stay on Zoom. We wanted to get out and live our lives again. Experiencing other people is always at the heart of what humans find truly enjoyable.  Products like the vision pro are extremely isolating and take you away from reality, rather than enhancing it. Now inevitably more and more people will buy them and so maybe this will change as and when they become mainstream and easier to wear etc, but I really feel that humanity does have a ceiling to how much we want technology in our lives.  However much it might be difficult and tricky at times, experiencing reality with the people we love is still the best thing that we have, however cringey that may sound.

Vision Pro and Meta glasses are not the starting point for developments toward the same goal.  However, I am sure that both will contribute to the development of future products that lie somewhere in between. Meta glasses are designed to be worn in any situation and anywhere (so that Meta can access data everywhere and ultimately make money from it). Vision Pro is the situation. Just because it has a battery doesn't mean you have to walk around with it on the street. Why would you? It's obviously designed for immersive entertainment, work, etc. in VR and AR. You put it on when you need it and take it off when you're done. Smart glasses, on the other hand, are designed to provide access to the digital world anytime, anywhere. It's more like a purpose-built tool versus a permanent digital connection.

Great review,  Honestly I am not a fan of comparing the smart glasses to HMDs.  I feel like smart glasses are more of head mounted smart watch, a companion to your phone, a quicker access to phone type information with a limited display for the sake of convenience. I know no one that uses passthrough on a headset outside of trying it for the first time or some sort of art project.  I feel like it was pushed because back when quest came out it sold headsets (or they thought it did).  They should just let them be different things.  I don't want to walk around with a computer on my face and I don't want to play a game on my watch.

I think the VR/XR space has been moving towards the "smart glasses" form factor because companies have just failed to realize the biggest use case for more immersive VR. Immersive VR is not just a smartphone on your face with a fancy HUD like smart glasses are. Sure, it could act as a productivity tool like a phone or laptop, but Immersive VR is primarily a social and entertainment platform. I want to be able to build a whole virtual world for myself not constrained by real world limitations like expensive furniture, real estate, or even the laws of physics. I want to be able to create a highly customizable avatar to represent myself that could be genuinely anything humanoid. Not just a generic metahuman.   People could invite their friends who live far away to hang out in their world, watch TV, play games, or explore other worlds together. It could enable socialization thousands of miles away. It could transcend language barriers. It could give disabled people the ability to walk, hell even fly if they wanted to. It could enable trans or genderfluid people to inhabit a body they actually feel comfortable in when they look in the mirror. It could enable people to experience the wonders of the world when travel is financially out of reach. VRchat may be old, niche, and get a bad reputation. However, it is the perfect example of a VR application with a VERY dedicated, growing, creative userbase. If a social platform like that could be created for a mainstream audience and made available through an easy to use, high quality headset I guarantee you it would take off. You cannot tell me that would not be a smash hit that moves units. Its ability to double as a productivity device would just be a bonus.

I find myself far more intrigued by augmented reality (AR) than virtual reality (VR). While VR has its place in the entertainment and gaming world, AR strikes me as the more practical and transformative technology for real-world applications. The ability to overlay digital information seamlessly onto our physical environment has enormous potential across industriesâ€”from education and design to healthcare and field service. Perhaps thatâ€™s why we see fewer polished consumer options at the moment; meaningful AR integration requires more complexity and refinement. That said, pricing models like $3,500 for a headset still feel excessive given the current stage of the technology. Just my perspectiveâ€”but I see AR as the true path forward. Great video as always.

I spent years trying to tell people full on VR isn't the future. But they kept pointing to TV and Movies showing how amazing and incredible it could be. They had this idea in their head based on a fake reality that they were building their decisions off of. Full on VR was NEVER the answer. Ever. It is a novelty. Always has been. There's 3 things a new product needs to do at least 2 of to gain adoption. It needs to be more efficient, it needs to replace something we already do and be better than the current version, and it needs to be easy to learn/get involved.  Is VR more efficient? No, you need to tailor everything around the headset like space, trusting the people around you not to mess with you, and making sure everything in your vicinity is basically blind person proof. Is it better than what we currently have? In some ways sure, but a lot of people prefer just gaming on a tv or multi tasking with an iPad and phone. And is it easy to get involved? No, you can't pick up and play, it's a whole extra investment for something not that intuitive, it's not that simple.  VR was NEVER the future and I'm so glad people have stopped pretending they're going to live in an Apple VR headset.

Not tried the smart glasses but a buddy has the apple vr and whilst it's extra difficult for me as a spectacles wearer (the design certainly isn't catered to that particular cohort) at first it is an amazing experience....but it soon becomes tiresome, the os is not easily learned by non enthusiasts and there are no compelling games or experiences as yet, I was always happy my turn was over and couldn't wait to get the contraption off my head....my buddy was an early occulus investor so I've had the experience of seeing vr develop as a non-enthusiast and from my particular perspective they are still way way off from having a useful product...i don't know if it's the weight or just the vr experiences effect on my body but every single time I've had a headset on, from the first occulus to the apple device, after about 10 minutes l get this raised area, about a cm in width, starting above one ear, circling the back of my head and finishing at my other ear....i think it's a vein (tho it genuinely feels much more solid than a typical vein, there is zero sponginess in it's texture) that is otherwise never called into action during my normal life, and it feels like it's constricting my head, it's not painful but it's most definitely uncomfortable and it comes as a blessed relief to take the headset off, I've often wondered if it's something to do with my eyesight as I'm very short sighted and often have had to remove my glasses to fit into the set, then again I've thought it might be a side effect of my senses struggling to adapt to vr or like I say it could just be the weight on my head for an extended time causing it, I don't suffer from migraines but from what I've read about them it sounds a little like one of the symptoms....anyways I seriously doubt these things will take off until they can solve this problem because if its happening to me it's undoubtedly happening to many others and if it is something to do with sensory overload they have a serious problem

Marques, hereâ€™s a real world review on an almost daily use case from an owner. I do have some caveats. - I love Apple products - I own a couple tech companies - been doing VR for over 14 years  OK with that out of the way on a scale of one to 10 based on the competition, I feel that the Apple Vision Pro gets a solid 8â€¦ in its current form. I believe it or not. I believe the only way to get it to a 10 (it pains me to say this) is if another company made the software.  Iâ€™m gonna be straight up Apple did some great things with the Vision Pro. But just like with iOS, Appleâ€™s gonna tell you what theyâ€™re gonna do. For example, we donâ€™t get videos on our lock screens. Why? Because Apple has to protect us from ourselves and battery usage instead of giving us the choice. Can we put the icons anywhere? No, they have to be in a grid. Stuff like this drives me nuts about Apple but thereâ€™s a new one for the Apple Vision Proâ€¦ native, and snake oil ğŸ˜¬.  Apple gives us the ability to install all iOS and iPadOS apps on our vision prosâ€¦ but the fine print is the developer has to opt in. So yes, on a plane I can watch anything from Disney+. But the content that I consume daily is on YouTube. Google opted it out so we canâ€™t even put the iPad app on the Vision Pro. Why does this matter? I pay for YouTube so I would like to have downloaded items ready. Whatâ€™s my work around? Download them on my iPad and share my iPad screen to my headset. Ugh. This is a major pain because I canâ€™t do this with Netflix either.    And then comes the native apps. Come on Apple! A killer app would be going through Apple Maps in complete VR!! how do I know this? Because if youâ€™ve never used Google Earth 14 years ago on the oculus rift, you have no idea what youâ€™re missing. I think Google made the perfect app and I am not a fan of Google at all. You could legitimately grab the sun and move the sun around the Earth and change how things look in real time. You can fly in from orbit and zoom all the way down to street view. This was a phenomenal way of using the Maps. And I think Apple Maps is better so the Fidelity would be better plus weâ€™re using much more powerful chips. But calendar, maps, numbers, etc. are all iPadOS apps. Sure at least they checked the check box to make sure it can be installed on the Apple Vision Pro, but damn I really wish it was native. And immersive.   I use my headset approximately 5 to 7 hours a day for work. I work mobile so I donâ€™t have the luxury of having a really bad ass home set up. But when Iâ€™m on the road, I whip out my laptop and have a massive screen. I donâ€™t go with the Ultra Wide but I do go with the wide screen and thatâ€™s perfect for anything that I need to do on my laptop. However, I wish I didnâ€™t have to take out my laptop. I wish I could have the experience from my laptop inside the headset because I have more space to work with.    Now it sounds like Samsungâ€™s product will work with all mobile apps. I canâ€™t stress enough how amazing this is. For example, gaming. I have some iPadOS games that are installed in the headset and all I have to do is turn on my headset and take my PlayStation five controller and now Iâ€™m gaming. However, Fortnite is now available for the iPadOSâ€¦. But I canâ€™t play it in the headset so what do I do? Loaded up on my iPad and share my iPad screen. Totally unnecessary, but it works. What about Call of DutyÂ®? Talk about an amazing experience inside the headset. But the developer opted out. It seems like Samsung wonâ€™t have this issue. People have no idea until it hits the market how amazing the Samsung product is going to be for gaming. Now imagine once these headsets start having PlayStation five level chips inside of themâ€¦. You literally have a console on your face where you can play in 8K pretty much anywhere. And donâ€™t even get me started on the Apple Intelligence versus Googleâ€™s or anybody elseâ€™s. I feel like Appleâ€™s product had a two year on the market head start, and is gonna lose it immediately.   Do I watch movies on my headset? Every now and then, but I consume more YouTube than any other media.   Sidenote, I picked up another headset from my wife, and when Iâ€™m out of town, we still watch our shows together just remotely on the headset and she loves itâ€¦ but after a couple, our long shows, she is done with the weight of the headset. I donâ€™t notice it because I guess since Iâ€™ve been doing it for 14 years, I developed the muscle muscles that are needed to not feel the weight. I donâ€™t know. Iâ€™ve never had issues with weight from headsets and Iâ€™ve owned every quest and every rift on my way to the Apple Vision Pro.  But anyway, thatâ€™s my honest review, and Iâ€™m a fanboy. Lol. I might pick up the other strap, but as of right now I feel like Appleâ€™s dropping the ball on the software. But I still give it a solid eight out of 10 for experience I wanted to rate and lower, but I felt like thatâ€™s not accurate. Thatâ€™s just my emotion. lol. I donâ€™t know if you read these but let me know what you think.

I'm confused by the lack of progress on the headset front. I mean, I get the social stigma stuff (and that's real - I've brought my Quest on the last couple flights I've taken and the flights have been so packed, I just didn't feel comfortable pulling it out). But the capabilities these headsets have should be making developers salivate. Everyone knows the holy grail of VR is essentially to create Westworld. If they accomplish that, it would literally be the biggest social advancement since AT LEAST social media, if not ever. But it feels like even knowing that, development is still contingent on people embracing VR wholesale in the interim and that feels like a foolish strategy. Most adults aren't gamers, so expecting them to adopt what right now is essentially gaming technology before the more mainstream offerings are available is unrealistic. I know plenty of people who would love to enter The Matrix but aren't going to prime themselves with Gorilla Tag or Beat Saber for a couple years while what they want is being developed. I think this tech is one of the few examples where you need to build it out FIRST and then the market will respond. I get that that's risky but I feel like this is as sure a bet as it gets, just knowing human tendencies. People will WANT to go to different realities, be whoever they want to be, and interact with interesting people.

I want to see something that is in-between the smart glasses and the AR headsets come out. Funnily enough, right now it seems like the larger AR headsets are happy with at least a battery in your pocket (we could probably do with some compute components in there and then a clip for your waistband so it can still dissipate heat to lighten up the headset), and the smart glasses try to cram everything into the glasses. This just ends up making the glasses look super clunky. Why not have all of the compute and battery for the smart glasses in something you can put in your pocket and just a magnetic connector that can snap onto either arm? This would enable the glasses to look much more normal when you don't care about using the smart features. Also, I think smart glasses need to ditch the speakers. Almost everyone has wireless earbuds. Save the space and keep the arms nice and thin and cut the speakers out.

If Apple wants Vision Pro to evolve toward a Ray-Ban Meta form factor, they need to rethink the system architecture. Right now everythingâ€”compute, sensors, displays, power, coolingâ€”is packed into the headset. Instead, Apple could split it into two parts: lightweight glasses for displays and cameras, plus a pocket or belt-mounted compute/power module (or leverage the iPhone). A dedicated ultra-low-latency wireless link, something in the 60 GHz+ range, could stream high-bandwidth video both ways with predictive buffering to mask any delay.  That would drop face weight, heat, and bulk while keeping performance. It also makes the platform modular: swap the compute pack every few years, keep the glasses. It wonâ€™t reach true â€œsunglassâ€ scale until micro-LED waveguides, compact eye-tracking, and dense batteries matureâ€”but this hybrid setup is the only practical path to getting Vision closer to that Ray-Ban-level comfort

1. Apple's Vision Pro 2 features the new M5 chip, enhancing performance and efficiency.  2. The design remains largely unchanged, maintaining the original's dimensions and materials.  3. Comfort improvements focus on a new dual knit band for better weight distribution.  4. Incremental upgrades include faster app loading and slightly improved battery life.  5. The Vision Pro's high price tag remains unchanged at $3,500, despite minor updates.  6. Competition in the mixed reality space is limited, with few comparable premium headsets.  7. Smart glasses are gaining popularity, offering practical features with less social stigma.  8. Apple's Vision Pro usage stats indicate limited engagement beyond media consumption.  9. Future development may shift towards smart glasses rather than heavy headsets.  10. The mixed reality market is evolving, with companies exploring different technological approaches.

Smart glasses are the exact opposite: they can't fully immerse you, they offer an overlay on top of reality, with a comfortable pair of glasses you can wear all day. We don't have to proclaim a winner. This sounds like comparing a phone to a computer. They will never be the same, and they shouldn't be, even if there's a small number of people who can do their work with both anyway.

You can't compare smart glasses to vision pro. They're literally polar opposites. AVP is for Immersion. Smart glasses are for day to day utiltiy , like a smart watch, just on your face.   You can't watch a 4K HDR movie on a smart glasses like you can on AVP. You cant do proper / immersed work on smart glasses like AVP. You can't run demanding 3D Apps like AVP. Etc. etc. etc.  2 totally different markets/use cases.   Now, AVP can always get slimmer, lighter and cheaper. Even so, even if they made it 30% lighter, 50% price drop ($1.5K) - there is no denying that more people will prob want to buy a $1K pair of smart glasses from Apple vs AVP. Just because of the look/feel and comfort alone. I get it. But both markets/products can co exist.

Like deliberately the vision pro isn't a consumer level device. But more like... hey, if there was a device like the Virtual Reality displays the Juassic Park doctors were using, what would it need to do to work? Ok, let's work on solving those problems and see what people do with the tech. Some of it will be for high level R&D tasks like that, classic Tony Stark manipulating 3D objects in space to fix things. And some of it will be as authoring devices for lower end devices. Carter here

I want to cook without taking my eyes off the movie, walk the dog, jog in the evening/morning twilight, ride a bike, or go shopping. I don't want a cable tugging me to my phone/battery on my belt. Give me lightweight, completely clear aviator glasses with a display and removable tinted lenses, put the battery and ALL the electronics, including the processors, in a separate unit on my neck like a Viture necklace, and let me watch movies, TV shows, and read books, comics, and manga, but for at least 10-12 hours without recharging, not just a couple of hours. I'm comfortable wearing heavy, full-size headphones around my neck; it's definitely more comfortable than having that weight on my nose or on a wire in my pants. Leave only the displays, glasses, and camera on my nose, maybe. I don't need a dumb AI assistant that understands only every third word. The camera isn't that heavy, and I can live without the hand-tracking video system; the virtual keyboard is inconvenient anyway. Gaming with glasses is also unnecessary, considering how many dongles and pairing time it requires.
